Header.title: Uttar Pradesh's Famous Chikankari
Header.paragraph: Chikankari is a traditional embroidery technique from India, known for its delicate and artfully done hand embroidery on a variety of textile fabrics like cotton, chanderi, muslin, georgette, viscose, silk, organza, net, etc. The embroidery is usually done on cool, pastel shades of light muslin and cotton garments. Nowadays, chikan embroidery is also done with colored and silk threads in colors to meet the fashion trends and keep chikankari up-to-date

About.text: Chikankari is a traditional embroidery style that originated in Lucknow, India. The word chikan means embroidery in Hindi, and kari means work, hence the name Chikankari. There are several theories about the origin of Chikankari. One theory suggests that it stems from the white-on-white embroidery of Shiraz, which came to India as part of a culture of Persian nobles at the Mughal court 1. Another popular origin story credits Noor Jahan, Mughal empress and wife of Jahangir, for introducing Chikankari to India 1. Chikankari is believed to have originated in the 17th century during the reign of the Mughal Emperor Akbar. Historical records suggest that he was a patron of the arts and encouraged the development of various crafts. The name not only signifies the meticulous craftsmanship but also highlights the sophistication and grace associated with the delicate white-on-white embroidery that characterized the early forms of Chikankari.

Services.text: Umar Miyan is a renowned Chikankari artisan from Lucknow, India. He has been involved in the art of Chikankari for several generations. His work is recognized for its intricate designs and meticulous execution. Umar Miyan has shared his knowledge and skills with younger generations, ensuring the continuation of this traditional craft

Khushboo Sharma is a connoisseur of Chikankari and a passionate advocate for the artisans who create this craft. She has written extensively about the art of Chikankari and the challenges faced by the artisans who uphold this tradition. Despite the low wages paid to these artisans, Sharma has highlighted their dedication and skill in her writings

Testimonials.text: The motifs and patterns in Chikankari were influenced by Persian and Central Asian art forms, reflecting the Mughal Empire's cultural synthesis.

The mid-20th century witnessed concerted efforts to revive Chikankari. Artisans and craft enthusiasts recognized the cultural significance of this traditional embroidery and worked towards its preservation and promotion.

Chikankari embroidery uses 32 different stitches, including backstitch, chain stitch, hemstitch, and others. The patterns and effects created depend on the stitches and the thicknesses of the threads used

Features.title: What is Chikankari
Features.text: 1. *Chikan (چکن):- The word Chikan in Persian means skilled embroidery or embroidery with grace. This term aptly captures the essence of the delicate and intricate embroidery work that defines Chikankari. 2. **Kari (کاری):*- Kari translates to craftsmanship or work in Persian. It denotes the skill and artistry involved in creating the hand-embroidered patterns characteristic of Chikankari.
